reviewText:
I recently bought the Reloaded version of the game, and was gutted to find load problems meant i couldnt play. So i hit the review button and let rip!

Then something magical happened, a dev made it all better. Let me repeat that. A dev made it BETTER! Not worse. Not promising to fix it in 6 months. Not blaming anyone else. Not getting my review deleted, or sending me dog poop in the mail. Better, and he did it on a weekend and sent me a message to say so.

Well im not far enough into the game to really tell what is like. But at the £5 price break is seems solid enough. Afterall if the dev can be bothered im sure gonna give it a fair crack of the whip and come back and review it properly later.

Now take my fiver and buy a cold beer with it. I salute you.

Update: Well this is tough for me. I really wanted to be able to say this is a great game and you will love it garanteed. But its not that straight forward. The Devs obviously care about this game and the players, but like a resue dog the game bears many scars from its tough and abusive past.

For me i didnt find one single thing thats wrong with this game, rather a collection of minor (but basic) gripes that just made the game rather hard work. For me it really highlights how clever a game like XCOM is and explains why they cost so much to make. Its hard to make things seem simple.

Firstly although there are some nice ideas around mouse contols, controlling the troops doesnt feel that enjoyable, and in my first few missions i never did work out if there was even a simple way of rotating troops (so i guess that means there isnt!). This is important due to a harsh Line-of-sight mechanic that means you while you look out from cover you might not see the guy running accross the open car park toward you because he was 1 square to the side of your LOS.

Next pacing. At the moment I think this is where the past abuse shows the most. The gameplay vs the business model is still a bit muddled. At the begining cash is so short that you cant afford basics like paying the mercs wages and health packs never mind guns and armour. It still thinks its a pay-to-play and it made me feel less 'special forces' and more 'special needs' while i rummaged through my fallen foes and the bins looking for a half eaten KFC to keep the team going.

I dont want to sound too down though. For a fiver i think it is ok value, and if you like turn based games its worth ago because its solid enough that you might really like it and all the minor bits might not bother you. Plus with the devs working hard to get the game back to how they want it, many of my gripes may disapear over time. But at the moment i just didnt find the gameplay that fun or adictive like XCOM, Shadow Run, or even Silent Storm and have drifted away for now to play other stuff.

I can't bring myself to change my recommendation. But is more of a yes-maybe, than a yes-yes
voteText: 76 of 88 people (86%) found this review helpful 10 people found this review funny

reviewText:
Genre - Turn based squad combat

I was never a massive player of the orignal Jagged Alliance games, but got quite into the online version and enjoy these type of games.

They have now released a one off payment version of the same game with added achievements etc. As the price was quite reasonable I thought I'd give it another go. It kept all my progress, which is handy and I have been able to play a couple of missions. The game plays the same as the online version without pesky micro-transactions. You unlock missions across the map as your mercs progress and can upgrade their weapons/armour/ammo with those you buy or find. You also have a mini-base to upgrade, if that takes your fancy.

It is a fun turn based game and although there are some limitations like no higher ground or explosions. The combat is still enjoyable and now it can't be accused of being P2W. Although I think they would be silly not to offer some mercs as permanent DLC. Luckily I was able to carry two of mine across already.

At a price of £5-£6 I think you should definately get your monies worth for a casual turn based combat game. The developers also appear to be fairly active and hope they will continue to support it. There is also a multiplayer mode if you want to fight other pesky humans,

However, I have been told it is isn't the best JA game, so you will have to ask a real fanboy for that.
voteText: 29 of 37 people (78%) found this review helpful 3 people found this review funny

reviewText:
I was nostalgic about JA2 so I tried it out.
I don't care much for PvP (I'm likely a tiny minority here) so just wanted to try single player and get back into turn-based shooting carnage.
And I did enjoy it! The details and variety of the mercs, weapons, armour and crafting options was cool. I like to do a bit of micromanaging anyway. Of course, there's no grand strategy mechanics like in JA2 - just playing bland missions after another. It's a good way to kill time while I'm rendering my videos.
voteText: 16 of 18 people (89%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
A fun game that gets increasingly challenging (and a little less linear) as you progress. For long-time Jagged Alliance fans, this is more similar to JA: Deadly Games than JA1 or JA2 due to it's mission based approach. If you buy this expecting an open world, RPG/Strategy game like the classic JA2, you will be disappointed. If you are looking for a well made turn-based strategy game, then JA Online Reloaded might be exactly what you are looking for. Just give it time because the difficulty of the missions, and the quality of the AI, improves after the first dozen or so missions.

I also want to quickly say how impressed I have been by the responsiveness of the developers. There was a major issue on launch day that prevented me from playing the game. A developer responded to my query within 30 seconds of asking it and they worked through the night (on a weekend) to fix it.
voteText: 15 of 17 people (88%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
A pretty decent turn based game.

It has a solid cover system.
Stealth, sneaking, perception and noise play a role.
The action point system gives a lot of choices fpr each merc in each round:
- moving to better position, maybe even flanking to hit on the lighter armored sides & back?
- aiming up for better chance to hit?
- go for headshots causing interesting status effects?
- move to cover and crouch behind it for minimum exposure?
- fall back and save action points to make an interrupt?
- ...

the classes feel well balanced, I love my Sniper, Commando, Gunner, Soldier Team a lot, but I know almost any other constellation would work out as well.

there is really a lot of stuff to loot or buy in the shop, you will be constantly switching gear, crafting new items and perfecting the teams equipment.

from what I can tell from the previous version, there is easily 40-50 hours of pure single player campaign play time.

however, there are still some cons:
- the alliances of players you can join play only a small optional role
- matchmaking will often stop looking for players of your level and match you up with better players (hard to win) or weaker ones (not very fun)
- while some contracts/levels still look pretty nice, some others (most of whats indoor cellar stuff for example) looks a bit dated

nevertheless, even though I already completed this, I really like the new model and am looking forward to play the fresh content that has been added.

I also like how active the devs are and hope for some more little updates in the future.
Knifes and grenades would be killer!

reviewText:
Loading issue seems to be fixed, still wouldn't recommend it.

Between this and SRC, both of their games, I would say SRC is better, but both seem lacking.  They don't really live up to the names behind them...

To put it simply they failed to heed this advice:

Never half-♥♥♥ two things whole-♥♥♥ one thing.
-Ron Swansons

There are little things like not being able to rotate the camara so when there is ♥♥♥♥ in the way it's hard to postion your mercs and the boundries for max movemnet like to fade away...

And then there appears to be a huge problem with how low income is in this game is.  Maybe I'm doing something horribly wrong but it seems like it's impossible to get enough money to equip more than one merc with good gear.  You get like 1k or 2k for indivudal missions, the price of things such as a single med pack is 2.6k and leveling a merc is around 1k at this reward level.
Then you get around 10k the price of one good peice of equipment for completing a contract...

So by the time I finish a contract I can get 1 weapon or 1 piece of armor for one merc and by the time I complete the next contract that gear is ♥♥♥♥ and needs to be upgraded...

reviewText: A much more polished update to the Jagged Alliance franchise than either Back in Action or Flashback turned out to be.  The mechanics are more simplistic than JA2 v1.13 or 7,62 + BSM, but it's a decent TBS game, nonetheless, and the convenient, accessible multiplayer PvP is entertaining.

reviewText:
So far so good.  I'm having a lot of fun.  I am not into p2w titles so much prefer buying and owning the game and all content with no paywalls or microtransactions.

To me it is well worth the money.  Is it JA 2 with patch 1.13?  No, but it is still fun.

It has moderate base building, so far the story mode and combat has been entertaining.  I am not sure how pvp works at the end game, but if it takes 60 hours to get to it, and I don't enjoy the end game, getting to it and having fun is still a great deal for $10, or 8.50.

reviewText:
I played over 200 hrs when JAO was first released.
I own every single JA game and finished all of them.

JAO I would recommend to people that have played the other JA games like I have.  Why?  Because this game has all the turn-based-tactics-goodness of all the others (minus the awesome characters of JA2, but no other JA game comes close either), albeit, in it's own, slightly different emphasis on simplistic gameplay...less micromanaging your team and more importance placed on acquiring/buying equipment and weapons.  The upgrading of your base is not my cup of tea, but I guess looking at the original monetization model, it is understandable.

This was the first JA title that encouraged" me to go online and play with other humans... I was hesitant at first and got my ♥♥♥ handed to me most of the time.  But I did enjoy it.

So
date: give it a try.  At this price-point
voteText: true

reviewText:
Game is OK, but... the bigest problem with it is that it does not live up to original title. And I am not talking about graphics or physics, but really balancing a game. some of example that are really anoying are:
you can only see (and) shoot a person with sniper rifle from distance of some 20 meters. So you shoot ar a person in the head and most likely that person will run into you and shoot with machinegun. there is 0% chance to hit with a rifle if a person is cjust next to you. No grenades. No knifes. Lack of logic in general behavior.
In short it is missing some core components that made Jagged Alliance a great game of that time.

I will still recomend it for people who did not play original.

reviewText:
Tried to like this game but it's pointless. Owing to the low money you get for missions, you can't equip all of your team with decent equipment. Subsequently later levels become an exercise in frustration. Only rarely, after repeadtedly redoing earlier levels, did I ever manage to get some decent equipment, but no extra cash (in game). Can't even afford medical equipment much less decent weapons and body armor.

Not that it matters, no matter what I do, my mercs are instaintly overwhelmed and cut to peices within three-five turns. Repeated requests to fix the imbalances have been ignored such substantially lower the prices in the store and increaseing the rewards would help. Most other games your characters can use things like explosives and knives, but they seem to be unable to add those items here.

So unless you enjoy hour after hour of frustration and tedium, avoid this game. And hope that one day soon someone will finally make a truly great new Jagged Alliance game.

reviewText:
Upon release, was initially stuck at loading screen; developer has fixed this and it's working now.

Game still pretty mediocre as far as turn based strategy goes. Laughable and repetitive voice acting. Inability to rotate camera. Perception system and mechanic seems off to me.

Very linear missions. If Gus Tarballs wants me to take out more bikers in the USA, I guess that's what I'll do because there's no other choice at this point. Everybody has to do the same PvE missions in order to upgrade their same hospital and same stoarge. One cannot even truly customize the hired mercs except by buying or finding equipment; there's an inability to change their names, outfits, or appearance.

The online component of game seems best suited for those interested in PvP, daily return rewards, and grinding the honor system so as to have their company name ranked on the leaderboard. Personally, I'm more interested in a single player experience.

Sight and Sound system is to basic, Enemy tactics are non existent (everyone is running in a straight line towards you, and they just stand around till they see you).
Commands for changing direction, run and crouch of your mercs are cumbersome.

It just isnt any fun to play PvE here.
I refunded the game and going back to JABIA.

reviewText: This game is OK, I played it when it was free to play. It limited the level I could get to with moderate gameplay so when the pay to own version came out I bought it and I was surprised that it had plenty of things for me to do to get higher level. I think it's worth the money to pay once to own the entire game. I am having fun and it's a good time killer. If you wait for it to go on sale, it's cheaper than a hamburger so give it a try if you like turn-based strategy games with the action-point system. I can't think of any cons at the moment so I will update this if I find any. Overall, I'd say if you get this game on sale it's worth it and I give it a thumbs up.
